title: New 'nuclear' peel promises to fade pigmentation caused by the summer heatwave

Summer may be long gone, but does your skin have a heatwave hangover?

It seems this year’s record-breaking sunshine has left us seeing sun spots, with UK Google searches for ‘dark pigmentation on face’ spiking after the hot spell.

‘A lot of people got caught out by the British sun this year,’ says dermatologist Dr Stefanie Williams, who’s seeing a very busy autumn of pigmentation woes at her Eudelo Clinic.

‘We’re less vigilant at using SPF at home, so a heatwave here puts us at high risk of irregular pigmentation,’ she adds.

It’s not just people who baked themselves silly who are dealing with pigmentation either.

‘If you’re already prone to pigmentation, even a tiny amount of sun exposure can trigger it,’ she adds.

Although pigmentation isn’t dangerous, it’s a real bugbear for many women who feel it makes their skin look older.

‘Society still sees youth as a hallmark of beauty, and patchy pigmentation is associated with ageing,’ says Dr Anjali Mahto, consultant dermatologist at 55 Harley Street and author of The Skincare Bible.

If your pigmentation doesn’t bother you, it’s perfectly safe to leave alone but if you’d rather be shot of it, now is the ideal time of year to start fading it out.

What am I seeing on my face?

(Image: Getty)

There are two main types of pigmentation that dermatologists treat

Chronic sun damage

Skin that’s had lots of sun over the years tends to develop an uneven, mottled tone all over, and there may be more defined sun spots too.

Melasma

This appears as darker patches on your face, which are larger than ‘age spots’ and often symmetrical.

It’s sometimes triggered by hormonal changes, due to pregnancy or contraceptive usage, for instance, but this isn’t always the case.

It typically fades slightly over winter, then rushes back each year at the first sign of sun.

Can I fade pigmentation without prescription?

Over-the-counter pigmentation lighteners might help, but they need to be part of a bigger skin regime, says Dr Mahto.

‘For best results, you need a combination of the right products at the right strength.’

(If you can’t afford pricey cosmeceutical brands, don’t despair, as brands like The Inkey List and The Ordinary do potency without the price tag.)

Oh and don’t forget the most important ingredient: patience.

‘It takes at least 12 weeks to see a real effect and most people give up too soon,’ she adds.

Here’s what she recommends for both types of pigmentation:

Retinol: The number one thing to try for pigmentation, says Dr Mahto. ‘Use it at night, starting once or twice a week and building up. Look for a minimum of 0.1%.’

Acids: AHAs and glycolics help shift pigmentation by shedding the top layers of skin. ‘Start gradually, using an AHA face wash once or twice a week. Or alternate retinol at night with a glycolic toner. Be careful not to overdo acids alongside retinol or you’re asking for irritation.’

Vitamin C: ‘Use in the morning. The best form is l-ascorbic acid, and at least 10% strength.’

Daily SPF50: Non-negotiable. ‘If you don’t use it, your pigmentation will come back. If you can’t commit to using it, everything else is a waste of money.’

Tranexamic acid is a clotting agent originally used for women with heavy periods, but it’s also been found to disrupt pigmentation production, says Dr Mahto.

‘Dermatologists are now using it off-license in short, sharp doses for melasma.’

It can be prescribed it orally, but it’s just starting to appear in skin products like SkinCeuticals Discoloration Defence, £85.

Anti-pigmentation products: ‘Formulas which target the enzymes involved in melanin production are worth including,’ says Dr Mahto.

Here are three of the latest formulas picked by Notebook’s beauty team:

Eucerin Anti-Pigment Serum, £38, uses a new active, thiamidol, to disrupt melanin. In a trial graded by dermatologists, it kept improving pigmentation over 12 weeks.

Dr Dennis Gross PRO IPL Dark Spot Concentrated Serum, £99, is pricey but packs a punch with 15% l-ascorbic acid, AHAs, lactic acid and licorice root. It claims to ‘rival 4% prescription strength hydroquinone’.

Boots No7 Laboratories Dark Spot Correcting Booster Serum, £38, claims it’s ‘clinically proven’ to reduce dark spots. In trials, testers saw effects from as soon as two weeks.

Is it worth seeing a dermatologist?

A dermatologist will be able to check your pigmentation is just that and nothing more sinister.

They can also offer stronger treatments like hydroquinone.

‘This is very effective and safe when used properly, but it’s prescription-only because if you use it for too long you can get a ‘rebound’ pigmentation that’s blue toned and very hard to remove,’ says Dr Mahto.

So definitely don’t be tempted to buy your own hydroquinone stash from the internet.

Dermatologists can also offer laser and IPL treatment, which can be very effective at zapping sun spots - but needs to be carried out by an expert.

‘I would advise against using IPL or laser with melasma,’ says Dr Williams.

‘You will get a lightening effect initially but then usually you get a rebound a few months later and could end up worse than you started.’

What’s the fastest way to shift pigmentation?

If 12 weeks sounds too long to wait, there is a quicker way, but be warned - it is the nuclear option.

(Image: Eudelo)

‘Specialist medium-depth peels give outstanding results if you can deal with the downtime,’ says Dr Williams.

‘Eudelo’s MelaOut peel reduces pigmentation by as much as 50% in four weeks and 80% after 12, but you can expect swelling and redness next day, followed by 1-3 weeks of flaking.

You’d definitely need to take a few days off work, but patients feel the results are worth it.’

(Image: Eudelo)

There are lighter peels with less downtime but it’s the full-on flaking that really blasts off the pigmentation.

Dr Stefanie Williams is medical director at Eudelo.

Dr Anjali Mahto is author of The Skincare Bible and consultant dermatologist at 55 Harley Street.
description: If pigmentation is the price you’ve paid for this summer’s record-breaking sunshine, here’s what you need to know about fading it
